page.title: 13Wildlife around Blakedown
page.content: The landscape of this area is covered with fields, hedgerows and small lanes. Badgers and foxes are the largest mammals but rabbits, mice, hedgehogs and voles are common. There are several small lakes, ponds and a number of streams that support a wide variety of aquatic life from frogs, newts and fish to water insects and water fowl. The most common local birds are blackbirds, sparrows, robins, thrushes and magpies. In the wooded areas you can find woodpeckers and owls. There are a lot of wild flowers that grow along the road verges and hedgerows. Although some of the old hedgerows have been removed to aid modern farming. Examples are fox glove, cow parsley and bluebells. In the autumn there are lots of fungi.
